Comment: In our openings, we need to consult the databases and opening books, and there are reasons why departures from established theory are bad -- they are dross in the crucible of experience.  In this game, black's first error comes on the fourth move, and a crucial blunder at move seven makes white's win inevitable.  Yet white, confident in the outcome, makes a lazy decision at move 14, prolonging the game unnecessarily.
?  This is a departure from established play (4. ... Be7), and it doesn't turn out well.  Unless black can now mobilize the queenside and castle over there, he is doomed.

White could have regained the gambit pawn with Qa4+, but to no strategic advantage.  I'm playing to expose black's king.

??  Bad move.  Black is behind in development and hasn't castled yet; putting the center in flux leads to his downfall.
Exposing black's vulnerable d-pawn . . .
When he promptly makes exactly the wrong move, losing immediately.  But 10. ... dxe5 doesn't look promising either.
11. ... Ne7 would have at least covered the king a bit, but 11. ... Qd8 was his best hope.

??  Still, 12. ... Qd8 was black's only chance.
??  Still, 12. ... Qd8 was black's only chance.

Why grab a pawn and trade queens?  An ending could have been forced sooner:  14. Nxe5 Qc5  15. Qf7+ Kd8  16. Rd1+ Kc7  (16. ... Kc8  17. Qd6+ leads to mate in 4) 17. Rd7+ Kb6  18. Rxe7 Qb4 (to prevent 19. Qb3+) 19. Qe6+ Ka5 20. Nc4+ and black must lose the queen, mate coming soon afterward.
